metadata.title: Mechanism of toxic effects of Nano-ZnO on cell cycle of zebrafish (Danio rerio)

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Chemosphere
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/chemosphere
Mechanism of toxic effects of Nano-ZnO on cell cycle of zebrafish (Danio rerio)
Jing Hou a, Haiqiang Liu a, Siyi Zhang a, Xinhui Liu b, Tasawar Hayat c, Ahmed Alsaedi c, Xiangke Wang a, *
a MOE Key Laboratory of Resources and Environmental Systems Optimization, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, 102206, PR China b Research Center for Eco-Environmental Engineering, Dongguan University of Technology, Dongguan, 523808, Guangdong Province, PR China c NAAM Research Group, Faculty of Science, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah, 21589, Saudi Arabia
h i g h l i g h t s
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: xkwang@ncepu.edu.cn (X. Wang).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chemosphere.2019.04.217 0045-6535/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
The genotoxicity of nano-ZnO to zebrafish based on cDNA microarray was evaluated. The nano-ZnO mainly affects the cell cycle pathway of zebrafish. Inhibition of Cyc/CDK complex expression leads to disorder of cell cycle process.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 21 February 2019 Received in revised form 28 April 2019 Accepted 29 April 2019 Available online 3 May 2019
Handling Editor: David Volz
Keywords: Nano-ZnO Toxicity Cell cycle DNA replication Cyclins
a b s t r a c t
The release of nano-zinc oxide (nano-ZnO) into the environment may lead to unpredictable risks, thus it is necessary to study its potential harm to organisms. In this study, zebrafish exposed to nano-ZnO were analyzed through cDNA microarrays to provide insight into the toxic effect of nano-ZnO on aquatic organisms at the molecular level. Results found that nano-ZnO inhibited the normal growth and development of zebrafish and other life activities by affecting the process of cell cycle. The nano-ZnO inhibited the expression of the cyclins (Cycs), cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) and the minichromosome maintenance (MCM), making the activation of Cyc/CDK complexs (CycD/CDK4, 6; CycE/CDK2; CycA/CDK2) and MCM fail and resulting in DNA replication disorder in different periods (G1, M and G2 phase). Therefore, the normal activities of individual organism such as cell division, differentiation and proliferation and the functions of DNA binding and intracellular transfer were disturbed. These findings contribute to our understanding of the toxicity of ZnO NPs to aquatic organisms, and also provide an evaluation basis for assessing the environmental impact of nano materials.
© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid development of nanotechnology, nano-materials have been widely used in various fields of life due to their special physical and chemical properties such as surface effect, small size effect, quantum size effect and macro quantum tunneling effect.
Nano zinc oxide (nano-ZnO), as a typical nano-material, is widely used in cosmetics, coatings, photocatalysts, medical antibacterial, water treatment, building materials and textile industry because of its dual characteristics of traditional ZnO and nano-materials (Khataee et al., 2015; Kołodziejczak-Radzimska and Jesionowski, 2014; Xiong, 2013). However, the applications of nano-ZnO in production and life have increased its exposure to natural organisms. Chen et al. found that nano-ZnOmainly remained in the lungs after entering the human body through breathing, and only a small part was excreted in the form of feces (Chen et al., 2010). At the same time, the nano-ZnO used in food packaging has the opportunity to be transferred to the food itself and then absorbed by the human body through the intestines and stomach, thus posing a potential hazard to human health (Espitia et al., 2013; Paisoonsin et al., 2013). Additionally, nano-ZnO will inevitably enter the water environment and have toxic effects on aquatic organisms (Adam et al., 2014; Baker et al., 2014; Chen et al., 2014a; Li et al., 2014), thus threatening the ecosystem and human health.
Recently, the toxicity of nano-ZnO to aquatic organisms has been well studied by some researchers. Li et al. found that the LC50 of nano-ZnO to Escherichia coli was 500mg/L in bacterial culture solution, much higher than that of 0.1mg/L in pure water (Li et al., 2011; Dasari et al., 2013), which is closely related to the environmental behavior of nano-ZnO in the test solution. In addition, nanoZnO had a 72-h EC50 of 0.04mg/L to crescent algae, showing higher toxicity than nano-copper oxide and nano-titaniumdioxide (Aruoja et al., 2009). The 48-h EC50 and the 24-h EC50 of nano-ZnO to Daphnia magna was 3.2 and 0.18mg/L (Heinlaan et al., 2008), respectively, indicating that exposure time is also an important factor. As the most common species in aquatic ecosystem, the antioxidant enzyme defense system of fish is extremely sensitive to environmental pollutants, so many researchers focus on the toxic effects of nano-ZnO on fish using antioxidant enzymes as biomarkers (Ahmad et al., 2006; Oliveira et al., 2008). Zebrafish is currently recommended by the International Organization for Standardization as a model organism (Ensenbach and Nagel, 1997) and is widely used in toxicology, environmental protection and developmental biology (Ma et al., 2013). Li et al. showed that the 96-h LC50 of nano-ZnO to zebrafish was 1.79mg/L in embryonic stage and 4.62mg/L in adult zebrafish (Li et al., 2017).
At present, the generally accepted toxic mechanisms of nanoZnO on organisms mainly included the release of Zn2þ (Adam et al., 2014; Ma et al., 2013; Miao et al., 2010), the physical and chemical properties of nano-ZnO itself (Chen et al., 2014b; Cupi et al., 2015; Peng et al., 2011) and the generation of reactive oxygen radicals (ROS) (Barnes et al., 2013; Kao et al., 2012; Li et al., 2014). Applerot et al. suggested that the nano-ZnO was first absorbed by the cells of the lysosomal and then released Zn2þ, a higher concentration of Zn2þ in the cytoplasm caused mitochondrial dysfunction and thus activating the caspase proteindependent apoptosis pathway (Applerot et al., 2009). Adversely, Sharma et al. approved that Zn2þ released from nano-ZnO can cause the abnormal expression of stress-related genes and proteins in endoplasmic reticulum, thus rapidly activating endoplasmic reticulum through related apoptotic pathway rather than relying on Caspase-3 mitochondrial apoptosis pathway (Sharma et al., 2012). Some researchers also agree that the toxicity of nano-ZnO is not entirely determined by the release of Zn2þ, and its physical and chemical properties also play an important role (L opez-Moreno et al., 2017; Pullagurala et al., 2018). Furthermore, the ROS produced by nano-ZnO after photocatalysis could generate oxidative stress and cause damage to cell membrane, DNA, protein, and even cell death (Applerot et al., 2009). For example, the ROS produced by nano-ZnO can damage DNA of HepG2 cells and eventually led to cell apoptosis (Sharma et al., 2012). Although a large number of
studies have reported the toxicity of nano-materials to organisms (Han et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2019). These studies mainly focus on the toxic effects of nanomaterials on organisms through the observation of phenomena and the detection of physiological levels, but the mechanism of their toxic effects is still unclear. With the continuous development of life sciences, the mechanism of action can be revealed by molecular biological methods such as detecting the linear structure of nucleic acid and protein molecular level. In this paper, the toxic effect of nano-ZnO on zebrafish was studied, which will help us better understand the toxicmechanism of nano-ZnO on zebrafish and make up the deficiency of previous research mechanisms.
The purpose of this studywas to investigate the toxicity of nanoZnO on zebrafish and its mechanism of action at molecular level. In order to achieve the above objectives, we studied the gene expression changes in zebrafish muscle tissue of nano-ZnO by cDNA microarray analysis and RT-qPCR analysis. The toxicity mechanism of nano-ZnO to zebrafish was discussed in depth, and it was found that nano-ZnO seriously affected the cell cycle pathway, thus causing the growth and development of zebrafish to be hindered. These results will do help to better evaluate the impact of nano-ZnO on aquatic ecosystems.

sections.heading: 2.1. Experimental material
sections.text:
ZnO nanopowders (99.9%, <50 nm) used in this experiment were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Company (Shanghai, China), which were ultrasonically dispersed in deionized water to prepare 1 g/L stock solution for use. The stock solution can be diluted to the required concentration by gradient in subsequent experiments. Nano-ZnO suspensions were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Jem-2100F, Jeol, Japan) to investigate the size and shape of the particles. X-ray Diffraction (XRD, D8advance, Buker, Leipzig, Germany) was used to determine the crystal structure of nano-ZnO in 2q¼ 5 e70 with a scanning rate of 6 min 1. The hydraulic diameter distribution of nano-ZnO suspensions were measured by a mastersizer (Mastersizer 3000, Malvern, UK).
2.2. Adaptation of zebrafish
The experimental zebrafish (Danio rerio) were acquired from Chinese Research Academy of Environmental Sciences (Beijing, China). All the zebrafish were healthy and disease-free with an average weight of 61.2± 5.2 g and an average body length of 11.2± 2.1 cm. The water used for domesticationwas pre-aerated for 12 h to ensure sufficient oxygen, and maintained at a temperature of 23± 1 C, pH of 7.0e7.7, hardness of 245mg/L and dissolved oxygen of 5.3e6.5mg/L.
2.3. Determination of Zn in zebrafish
The culture medium of zebrafish was slightly modified according to the US EPA toxicity guidelines. Ten zebrafish domesticated for two weeks were placed in 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8, 16mg/L nano-ZnO solution, respectively. Three repetitions were set for different concentration to ensure minimum experimental error, each containing ten zebrafish individuals. All zebrafish were cultured in an incubator for 96 h with a day/night cycle of 16: 8 h without feeding during exposure. After the exposure period, zebrafish were taken and dried at 120 C for 12 h. Subsequently, the dried zebrafish samplewas ground and then digested with 70% nitric acid at 260 C for 30min. After cooling to room temperature, a 0.2-mm filter membrane was employed to filter out the digested residue and
1.5mL of 25% triethanolamine was added to neutralize the remaining acid in the solution. Zn content in samples was determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS, NexION300x, PerkinElmer Instruments Co., Ltd).

sections.heading: 2.4. Bioinformatics analysis
sections.text: Zebrafish was exposed to 0 and 1/10 LC50 of nano-ZnO solution for 96 h, and the semi lethal concentration (LC50¼ 4.78mg/L) used for cDNA microarray were based on our previous study (Hou et al., 2018). Genes with fold changes 2 and p< 0.01 were considered as differentially expressed genes (DEGs). The gene ontology (GO) enrichment analysis and the kyotoencyclopedia of genes and genomes (KEGG) pathway analysis were performed using OmicShare tools (www.omicshare.com/ tools).

sections.heading: 2.5. Real-time quantitative PCR
sections.text: The total RNA of zebrafish was extracted using RNAprep pure Tissue Kit (Tiangen Biotech Co., Ltd, Beijing, China), and reverse transcription was performed with FastKing RT Kit (Tiangen Biotech Co., Ltd, Beijing, China) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Primer 3.0 Online Software (http://primer3.ut.ee/) was used to design primer sequences of fourteen DEGs. RT-qPCR was performed with SYBR Green Real-time PCRMaster Mix Kit (Toyobo, Osaka, Japan) using StepOnePlus™ equipment (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The reaction parameters were set as follows: prereaction at 95 C for 5s, 95 C for 10s, 60 C for 10s, and then 72 C for 5 s; Cycle 35 times. Three biological repetitions were set for each treatment, and the relative expression was calculated by formula 2-DDct based on b-actin as the internal reference gene.

sections.heading: 2.6. Data analysis
sections.text: Statistical analysis of experimental data was performed with SPSS software (version 24.0, IBM, USA). Significancewas declared at p< 0.05. Experimental data are indicated as mean± standard error of three biological repetition (n¼ 3).

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of nano-ZnO
sections.text:
The nano-ZnO described in the TEM image confirmed the manufacturer's description of the size and shape of the particles (Fig. 1 A, C). The XRD patterns showed that the nano-ZnO had a grain-column hexagonal crystal structure (Fig. 1 B). Hydraulic size distribution of nano-ZnO in suspension is ranged from 141 to 295 nm (Fig. 1 D).
3.2. Zn content in zebrafish
Zn content in the zebrafish showed a linear increasing relationship as the concentration of nano-ZnO increased from 0.5 to 16mg/L (Fig. 2), suggesting that concentration is an important factor affecting the accumulation of Zn in zebrafish.

sections.heading: 3.3. Gene ontology enrichment analysis
sections.text:
A total of 4170 DEGs were screened from cDNA microarray according to the threshold of fold changes 2 and p< 0.01 (Fig. 3). The GO result performed with the DEGs showed that 166 biological process terms, 64 molecular function terms and 63 cellular component terms enriched among the 4170 DEGs, respectively (File
S1). The top twenty GO terms for each process were shown in Fig. 4 A-C. The nucleobase-containing compound metabolic process (GO:0006139) (p¼ 9.07 10 14), nucleic acid metabolic process (GO:0090304) (p¼ 3.44 10 12), and DNA metabolic process (GO:0006259) (p¼ 9.10 10 9) are the most enriched for biological process; membrane-bounded organelle (GO:0043227) (p¼ 1.89 10 7), intracellular membrane-bounded organelle (GO:0043231) (p¼ 1.89 10 7), and intracellular organelle (GO:0043229) (p¼ 2.12 10 6) are the most enriched for cellular component; methyltransferase activity (GO:0008168) (p¼ 1.66 10 5), transferase activity (GO:0016741) (p¼ 1.66 10 5), and nuclease activity (GO:0004518) (p¼ 5.05 10 4) are the most enriched for molecular function. Briefly, the toxicity of nano-ZnO mainly affects the function of cell metabolism in the biological process, the function of intracellular organelles in cell components, and the function of transferase activity in molecular functions.

sections.heading: 3.4. Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes pathway analysis
sections.text:
KEGG pathway analysis was performed on the 4170 DEGs to explore the functional relationship of genes. The results showed that 313 pathways (File S2) were enriched from the DEGs, and the most affected metabolic pathways (Fig. 4 D) were cell cycle (ko04110) (p¼ 4.26 10 6) and DNA replication (ko03030) (p¼ 8.62 10 5). The two pathways are very closely connected, because DNA replication is involved in the whole process of cell cycle (Hou et al., 2018). Cell cycle (Fig. 5) is the basic process of cell life activities, and cells undergo physiological phenomena such as proliferation, differentiation, aging and death during the evolution of their cycle phases. Generally, the division cycle of eukaryotic cells is divided into four consecutive phases: DNA synthesis prophase (G1 phase), DNA synthesis phase (S phase), DNA synthesis anaphase (G2) and mitosis phase (M phase). The occurrence and development of cell cycle is controlled by the cell cycle clock, and its functional state determines whether cells continue to proliferate or exit the cell cycle or enter a quiescent state. The core part of the cell cycle clock is composed of cyclins (Cycs) and cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), where CDKs are catalytic subunits that control a variety of cell reactions through phosphorylation or dephosphorylation of different substrates (Pavletich, 1999). Cycs are regulatory subunits, after binding to CDKs, guide CDKs to the corresponding reaction substrates and determine when and where to phosphorylate these substrates. Moreover, the cell cycle is negatively regulated by cyclin-dependent kinases inhibitor (CDKI) (Feldmann et al., 2011), which can specifically inhibit the activation of Cyc/CDK complex, thereby block cell cycle progression or induce cells to exit the activated proliferation cycle and enter retention phase (G0 phase). When the normal process of cell cycle was disturbed, the cells will take remedial measures to carry out regulation and control to prevent the occurrence of errors, which are the checkpoints of the cells. Different Cyc/CDK complexes are the determinants of these Chks. Once the internal and external environment of the cell changes, the cell integrates and transmits DNA damage and various signals at the checkpoints, which determineswhether the cell stops the differentiation process or programmed death occurs. After passing the Chks, cell division and DNA repair are basically selfcontrol processes within the cell. However, if environmental signals or changes in cell internal factors are not conducive to normal cell cycle activities, cell cycle will be disturbed again.
In the present study, three genes related to cell cycle were upregulated and 28 genes were down-regulated after exposure to nano-ZnO, including CDK, CDKI, ORC, Cyc, MCM (mini chromosome maintenance), and checkpoints that are closely related to cell cycle
regulation. From the G1 to S phase, the TGFb (transforming growth
factor beta-1) indirectly activates down-regulation of smad2_3 gene (mothers against decapentaplegic homolog 2/3), resulting in down-regulation expression of CDKI2b and CDKI1a downstream of smad2_3 gene. The activation of some Cyc/CDK complexs (CycD/ CDK4,6; CycE/CDK2; CycA/CDK2) were specifically inhibited, and the preparation of DNA synthesis was interrupted, thereby block cell cycle progression and stay in G1 phase without entering S phase. The up-regulation expression of CCND1 (G1/S-specific cyclin-D1) gene induced by nano-ZnO indirectly suggests that nano-ZnO may cause DNA damage of zebrafish cells in G1 phase. Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that MCM protein is an important member of the DNA replication system in S phase (Agmal et al., 2017). It participates in the important life processes of DNA replication, such as initiation, extension, transcription and
chromatin morphological regulation. It allows DNA replication once and only once per cell cycle (Labib and Tercero, 2000; Nguyen et al., 2001). The change of MCM expression in tissue caused by nano-ZnO directly affects DNA replication in cell cycle.
During the transition from S phase to G2 phase, the normal Sphase cells which passing the DNA damage checkpoint, indirectly act on DNA-PK (DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit) and ATM/ATR (serine-protein kinase ATM), where DNA-PK directly activates P53 (tumor protein p53) expression, while ATM/ATR activates p53 through phosphorylation of Chk1and Chk2 (serine/ threonine-protein kinase Chk1/Chk2). After p53 was activated, gadd45 (growth arrest and DNA-damage-inducible protein) was
prompted to down-regulate expression and then inhibit the activity of CycB/CDK1 complex (Smith et al., 1994). In addition, the down-regulation of Wee (wee1-like protein kinase) gene also inhibits activation of CycA/CDK1 and Cycb/CDK1 complexes through phosphorylation. Briefly speaking, the synergistic of P53 and Wee inhibits the activation of Cyc/CDK complex, causing G2 phase disorder of cell cycle.
The transduction from G2 to M phase was affected by the toxicity of nano-ZnO, down-regulation of MAD2 (mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint protein MAD2) and bub3 (cell cycle arrest protein BUB3) genes immediately inhibits the expression of downstream genes apc1 (anaphase-promoting complex subunit 1) and cdc20 (cell division cycle 20, cofactor of APC complex) (Davey and Morgan, 2016). The apc/cdc20 complex affects subsequent mitosis through two pathways. On the one hand, it affects the normal phosphorylation and dephosphorylation cycle of cdc25b (M-phase inducer phosphatase 2)-Plk1-Cycb/CDK1-Cdc25B, which plays an important role in the normal division of M phase (Smith et al., 1994). Another way is that apc/cdc20 complex inhibits PTTG (securin) expression through ubiquitination, and PTTG is an essential protease in the process of the dichotomy of chromatids (Andrea and Salmon, 2007).

sections.heading: 3.5. Gene expression
sections.text:
Details of genes and specific primer information were shown in Table 1. RT-qPCR results confirmed the accuracy of the cDNA microarray results, and the four genes involved in the cell cycle are shown in Fig. 6. As a transmembrane protein, claudin d (cldnd) mainly distributed on the membrane surfaces of brain, stomach and intestinal cells (Mineta et al., 2011), and closely associated with cell adhesion in tight junctions (Furuse et al., 1998). The cldnd gene plays an important role in regulating the entry of proteins that with the same structure into cells, in away that calcium does not depend on cell attachment (Zhao et al., 2013; Boran and Ulutas, 2015). In this study, the cldnd gene down-regulation in zebrafish suggested that cldnd is highly sensitive to nano-ZnO, and the abnormal expression of cldnd would affect the protein exchange between
cells and may lead to cell function loss or even abnormal apoptosis during cell cycle.
Geminin (gmnn) is a synaptic protein that negatively regulates DNA replication and cell cycle by the expression of associated genes (Mcgarry and Kirschner, 1998). Study by Siim and Ludovic, 2013 showed that the concentration of geminin increased in S and G2 phases, decreased at the end of M phase and was not detected in G1 phase (Siim and Ludovic, 2013). Similar result from Arib et al. also confirmed that gmnn gene plays a critical role as a regulator in cell cycle (Arbi et al., 2017). Geminin could show inhibition of DNA replication and negative regulation of cell cycle in S and G2 phases. gmnn gene down-regulated in present study indicated that the normal expression of GMNN was seriously inhibited by nano-ZnO, and the deficiency of geminin would cause excessive replication, cell type-specific DNA damage and G2/M stagnation (Klotznoack et al., 2012).
Nanog homeobox (nanog) is a transcription regulator distributed in the nucleus and binding to sequence-specific DNA. It
participates in the self-renewal of embryonic stem cells (Loh et al., 2006; Nichols et al., 1998) and plays a key role in maintaining undifferentiated state of pluripotent cells (inner cell mass, primordial germ cells) (Miyanari and Torrespadilla, 2012; Sun et al., 2014). Habibi et al. found that the number of trophoblast cells decreased significantly after knocking out nanog, indicating that the expression of nanog is closely related to the proliferation of trophoblast cells in the early embryo stage (Habibi et al., 2018). Moreover, many data show that nanog gene is abnormally expressed in the development of malignant phenotype of tumor cells and is considered as a potential biological and prognostic marker for malignant tumors (Cao et al., 2018; Sullivan et al., 2010). The down-regulation expression of nanog caused by nano-ZnO indicates that the function of embryonic stem cells was disturbed in M phase and even leads to the tumorigenesis of cells.
Topoisomerase II beta (top2b) is an enzyme that alters the topologic states of DNA during transcription, which engaged in DNA unwinding and recombination during DNA replication, as well as positive regulation of RNA polymerase II promoter transcription and ATP hydrolysis and binding (Li et al., 2017). At the same time, top2b gene has been proved to be an important motor neuron for axonal guidance and neurite growth (Yang et al., 2000).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The toxicity of nano-ZnO affects the normal process of cell cycle. From G1 to S phase, TGFb indirect suppression of smad2_3 gene expression increases the activity of CDKI2b and CDKI1a and then inhibits DNA synthesis preparation. As for S to G2 phase, the normal S-phase cells that passing the DNA damage checkpoint, after indirectly acting on DNA-PK and ATM/ATR, P53 was activated through phosphorylation, and resulting in abnormal DNA replication due to inhibition of CycA/CDK1 and Cycb/CDK1 complex expression. Transduction from G2 to M phase was also affected by the toxicity of nano-ZnO, down-regulation of MAD2 and bub3 inhibits apc/ cdc20 complex and affects subsequent mitosis through cdc25b and PTTG. Briefly, the toxicity of nano-ZnO leads to the disorder of DNA replication by inhibiting the expression of Cyc/CDKs complex in different periods (G1, M and G2 phase). Hence, the toxicity mechanism of nano-ZnO to zebrafish was well clarified from the molecular level, which provides in-depth insights for future studies on the toxicity of metal oxide nanomaterials to aquatic organisms, and also provides an evaluation basis for assessing the environmental impact of nano materials.
Declarations of interest
None.

referenceMentions.context: Nano zinc oxide (nano-ZnO), as a typical nano-material, is widely used in cosmetics, coatings, photocatalysts, medical antibacterial, water treatment, building materials and textile industry because of its dual characteristics of traditional ZnO and nano-materials (Khataee et al., 2015; Kołodziejczak-Radzimska and Jesionowski, 2014; Xiong, 2013).

Nano zinc oxide (nano-ZnO), as a typical nano-material, is widely used in cosmetics, coatings, photocatalysts, medical antibacterial, water treatment, building materials and textile industry because of its dual characteristics of traditional ZnO and nano-materials (Khataee et al., 2015; Kołodziejczak-Radzimska and Jesionowski, 2014; Xiong, 2013).

Nano zinc oxide (nano-ZnO), as a typical nano-material, is widely used in cosmetics, coatings, photocatalysts, medical antibacterial, water treatment, building materials and textile industry because of its dual characteristics of traditional ZnO and nano-materials (Khataee et al., 2015; Kołodziejczak-Radzimska and Jesionowski, 2014; Xiong, 2013).
found that nano-ZnOmainly remained in the lungs after entering the human body through breathing, and only a small part was excreted in the form of feces (Chen et al., 2010).

At the same time, the nano-ZnO used in food packaging has the opportunity to be transferred to the food itself and then absorbed by the human body through the intestines and stomach, thus posing a potential hazard to human health (Espitia et al., 2013; Paisoonsin et al., 2013).

Additionally, nano-ZnO will inevitably enter the water environment and have toxic effects on aquatic organisms (Adam et al., 2014; Baker et al., 2014; Chen et al., 2014a; Li et al., 2014), thus threatening the ecosystem and human health.

Additionally, nano-ZnO will inevitably enter the water environment and have toxic effects on aquatic organisms (Adam et al., 2014; Baker et al., 2014; Chen et al., 2014a; Li et al., 2014), thus threatening the ecosystem and human health.

Additionally, nano-ZnO will inevitably enter the water environment and have toxic effects on aquatic organisms (Adam et al., 2014; Baker et al., 2014; Chen et al., 2014a; Li et al., 2014), thus threatening the ecosystem and human health.
1mg/L in pure water (Li et al., 2011; Dasari et al., 2013), which is closely related to the environmental behavior of nano-ZnO in the test solution.

04mg/L to crescent algae, showing higher toxicity than nano-copper oxide and nano-titaniumdioxide (Aruoja et al., 2009).
18mg/L (Heinlaan et al., 2008), respectively, indicating that exposure time is also an important factor.

As the most common species in aquatic ecosystem, the antioxidant enzyme defense system of fish is extremely sensitive to environmental pollutants, so many researchers focus on the toxic effects of nano-ZnO on fish using antioxidant enzymes as biomarkers (Ahmad et al., 2006; Oliveira et al., 2008).

As the most common species in aquatic ecosystem, the antioxidant enzyme defense system of fish is extremely sensitive to environmental pollutants, so many researchers focus on the toxic effects of nano-ZnO on fish using antioxidant enzymes as biomarkers (Ahmad et al., 2006; Oliveira et al., 2008).

Zebrafish is currently recommended by the International Organization for Standardization as a model organism (Ensenbach and Nagel, 1997) and is widely used in toxicology, environmental protection and developmental biology (Ma et al.

Zebrafish is currently recommended by the International Organization for Standardization as a model organism (Ensenbach and Nagel, 1997) and is widely used in toxicology, environmental protection and developmental biology (Ma et al., 2013).

At present, the generally accepted toxic mechanisms of nanoZnO on organisms mainly included the release of Zn2þ (Adam et al., 2014; Ma et al., 2013; Miao et al., 2010), the physical and chemical properties of nano-ZnO itself (Chen et al.

At present, the generally accepted toxic mechanisms of nanoZnO on organisms mainly included the release of Zn2þ (Adam et al., 2014; Ma et al., 2013; Miao et al., 2010), the physical and chemical properties of nano-ZnO itself (Chen et al.

At present, the generally accepted toxic mechanisms of nanoZnO on organisms mainly included the release of Zn2þ (Adam et al., 2014; Ma et al., 2013; Miao et al., 2010), the physical and chemical properties of nano-ZnO itself (Chen et al.
, 2010), the physical and chemical properties of nano-ZnO itself (Chen et al., 2014b; Cupi et al., 2015; Peng et al., 2011) and the generation of reactive oxygen radicals (ROS) (Barnes et al.
, 2010), the physical and chemical properties of nano-ZnO itself (Chen et al., 2014b; Cupi et al., 2015; Peng et al., 2011) and the generation of reactive oxygen radicals (ROS) (Barnes et al.
, 2011) and the generation of reactive oxygen radicals (ROS) (Barnes et al., 2013; Kao et al., 2012; Li et al., 2014).
, 2011) and the generation of reactive oxygen radicals (ROS) (Barnes et al., 2013; Kao et al., 2012; Li et al., 2014).
, 2011) and the generation of reactive oxygen radicals (ROS) (Barnes et al., 2013; Kao et al., 2012; Li et al., 2014).

suggested that the nano-ZnO was first absorbed by the cells of the lysosomal and then released Zn2þ, a higher concentration of Zn2þ in the cytoplasm caused mitochondrial dysfunction and thus activating the caspase proteindependent apoptosis pathway (Applerot et al., 2009).

approved that Zn2þ released from nano-ZnO can cause the abnormal expression of stress-related genes and proteins in endoplasmic reticulum, thus rapidly activating endoplasmic reticulum through related apoptotic pathway rather than relying on Caspase-3 mitochondrial apoptosis pathway (Sharma et al., 2012).

Some researchers also agree that the toxicity of nano-ZnO is not entirely determined by the release of Zn2þ, and its physical and chemical properties also play an important role (L opez-Moreno et al., 2017; Pullagurala et al., 2018).
Furthermore, the ROS produced by nano-ZnO after photocatalysis could generate oxidative stress and cause damage to cell membrane, DNA, protein, and even cell death (Applerot et al., 2009).
For example, the ROS produced by nano-ZnO can damage DNA of HepG2 cells and eventually led to cell apoptosis (Sharma et al., 2012).
Although a large number of studies have reported the toxicity of nano-materials to organisms (Han et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2019).
78mg/L) used for cDNA microarray were based on our previous study (Hou et al., 2018).
The two pathways are very closely connected, because DNA replication is involved in the whole process of cell cycle (Hou et al., 2018).

The core part of the cell cycle clock is composed of cyclins (Cycs) and cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), where CDKs are catalytic subunits that control a variety of cell reactions through phosphorylation or dephosphorylation of different substrates (Pavletich, 1999).

Moreover, the cell cycle is negatively regulated by cyclin-dependent kinases inhibitor (CDKI) (Feldmann et al., 2011), which can specifically inhibit the activation of Cyc/CDK complex, thereby block cell cycle progression or induce cells to exit the activated proliferation cycle and enter retention phase (G0 phase).
Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that MCM protein is an important member of the DNA replication system in S phase (Agmal et al., 2017).
It allows DNA replication once and only once per cell cycle (Labib and Tercero, 2000; Nguyen et al., 2001).
It allows DNA replication once and only once per cell cycle (Labib and Tercero, 2000; Nguyen et al., 2001).
prompted to down-regulate expression and then inhibit the activity of CycB/CDK1 complex (Smith et al., 1994).

The transduction from G2 to M phase was affected by the toxicity of nano-ZnO, down-regulation of MAD2 (mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint protein MAD2) and bub3 (cell cycle arrest protein BUB3) genes immediately inhibits the expression of downstream genes apc1 (anaphase-promoting complex subunit 1) and cdc20 (cell division cycle 20, cofactor of APC complex) (Davey and Morgan, 2016).

On the one hand, it affects the normal phosphorylation and dephosphorylation cycle of cdc25b (M-phase inducer phosphatase 2)-Plk1-Cycb/CDK1-Cdc25B, which plays an important role in the normal division of M phase (Smith et al., 1994).

Another way is that apc/cdc20 complex inhibits PTTG (securin) expression through ubiquitination, and PTTG is an essential protease in the process of the dichotomy of chromatids (Andrea and Salmon, 2007).

As a transmembrane protein, claudin d (cldnd) mainly distributed on the membrane surfaces of brain, stomach and intestinal cells (Mineta et al., 2011), and closely associated with cell adhesion in tight junctions (Furuse et al.
, 2011), and closely associated with cell adhesion in tight junctions (Furuse et al., 1998).

The cldnd gene plays an important role in regulating the entry of proteins that with the same structure into cells, in away that calcium does not depend on cell attachment (Zhao et al., 2013; Boran and Ulutas, 2015).

The cldnd gene plays an important role in regulating the entry of proteins that with the same structure into cells, in away that calcium does not depend on cell attachment (Zhao et al., 2013; Boran and Ulutas, 2015).
Geminin (gmnn) is a synaptic protein that negatively regulates DNA replication and cell cycle by the expression of associated genes (Mcgarry and Kirschner, 1998).
Study by Siim and Ludovic, 2013 showed that the concentration of geminin increased in S and G2 phases, decreased at the end of M phase and was not detected in G1 phase (Siim and Ludovic, 2013).
also confirmed that gmnn gene plays a critical role as a regulator in cell cycle (Arbi et al., 2017).

gmnn gene down-regulated in present study indicated that the normal expression of GMNN was seriously inhibited by nano-ZnO, and the deficiency of geminin would cause excessive replication, cell type-specific DNA damage and G2/M stagnation (Klotznoack et al., 2012).

participates in the self-renewal of embryonic stem cells (Loh et al., 2006; Nichols et al., 1998) and plays a key role in maintaining undifferentiated state of pluripotent cells (inner cell mass, primordial germ cells) (Miyanari and Torrespadilla, 2012; Sun et al.
, 1998) and plays a key role in maintaining undifferentiated state of pluripotent cells (inner cell mass, primordial germ cells) (Miyanari and Torrespadilla, 2012; Sun et al., 2014).
, 1998) and plays a key role in maintaining undifferentiated state of pluripotent cells (inner cell mass, primordial germ cells) (Miyanari and Torrespadilla, 2012; Sun et al., 2014).

found that the number of trophoblast cells decreased significantly after knocking out nanog, indicating that the expression of nanog is closely related to the proliferation of trophoblast cells in the early embryo stage (Habibi et al., 2018).

Moreover, many data show that nanog gene is abnormally expressed in the development of malignant phenotype of tumor cells and is considered as a potential biological and prognostic marker for malignant tumors (Cao et al., 2018; Sullivan et al., 2010).

Moreover, many data show that nanog gene is abnormally expressed in the development of malignant phenotype of tumor cells and is considered as a potential biological and prognostic marker for malignant tumors (Cao et al., 2018; Sullivan et al., 2010).

Topoisomerase II beta (top2b) is an enzyme that alters the topologic states of DNA during transcription, which engaged in DNA unwinding and recombination during DNA replication, as well as positive regulation of RNA polymerase II promoter transcription and ATP hydrolysis and binding (Li et al., 2017).
At the same time, top2b gene has been proved to be an important motor neuron for axonal guidance and neurite growth (Yang et al., 2000).
